text.plotgw.page.title: LIGO Compact Binary Catalogue
text.plotgw.information.heading: Information:
text.plotgw.information.title: Information Panel
text.plotgw.information.subtitle: Click on datapoints for more information
text.plotgw.help.title: Help
text.plotgw.help.text:
Explore the LIGO compact binary catalogue, which is all the mergers of Black Holes and neutron stars detected by the LIGO detectors.

Click on the markers on the graph to show information about the various detections
text.plotgw.help.about: This web-app was written and is maintained by Chris North (Cardiff University). Source code is available on GitHub.
text.plotgw.help.tech: The points in this graph show the best fit values, which are the medians of the posterior probability distributions. The error bars indicate the 90% credible interval. All values are in the source frame of the source (i.e. no redshifts applied). Where applicable, the uncertainties assume astrophysical priors. Further details are available at the LIGO Open Science Center.
text.plotgw.help.info: Show information about the selected detection
text.plotgw.help.settings: Change the graph properties, such as the horizontal and vertical axes
text.plotgw.help.errors: Turn errors on and off, both in the graph and the information panel
text.plotgw.help.lang: Change the language the web-app is displayed in
text.plotgw.help.share: Share the web-app to friends and/or followers
text.plotgw.lang.title: Language
text.plotgw.lang.text: Chose your language from the options below
text.bub.page.title: Known Stellar-mass Black Holes
text.bub.footer:
Hosted by Cardiff University School of Physics and Astronomy.
Maintained by Chris North on behalf of the LIGO Scientific Collaboration. View the source on GitHub.
Gravitational Wave data from LIGO Open Science Center. X-ray binary data based on stellarcollapse.org/bhmasses.
text.bub.help.scalemass: Scale circle area by black hole mass
text.bub.help.scalesize: Scale circle radius by black hole radius
text.bub.help.tech: Gravitational wave source properties show either the best-fit values (medians of posterior probability distributions) or the 90% credible intervals. All values are in the source frame of the source (i.e. no redshifts applied). Further details are available at the LIGO Open Science Center.X-ray binary data is based on stellarcollapse.org/bhmasses.
share.plotgw.twitter.text: Look at this Binary Black Hole catalogue of @LIGO observations
share.bub.twitter.text: Look at this Black Hole Bubble Plot showing the  @LIGO observations
text.plotgw.april.title: New Releases
text.plotgw.april.text:
Following the full analysis of the LIGO data, and with a commitment to open data, it is only fair that the full collection of detections are released to the public.

To fully appreciate the significance of this data release, it is suggested that you look at the detections in redshift space, as well as in mass space.

The justification for this data release, which is not endorsed by the LIGO Scientific Collaboration or the Virgo Collaboration, is available here.

You can also return to the official data release.
